text: Somewhat aged 50 cl bottle from Drankencentrale De Moor. Pale beige, creamy, lightly lacing head settling into a moussy rim over a very dark bronze beer, close to blackish in general appearance, but with hazy mahogany-hued, translucent edges. Aroma of toasted walnuts, fondant chocolate, dried blueberries, sweet red wine, toffee, cold tea, toasted bread, old brownies, raisins, dry tree leaves. Dried fruits in the mouth, hints of fig and dried banana slices, restrained sweetishness with a very soft dried berry-ish sourish touch, softish carbonation, smooth and lightly oily mouthfeel. Nutty and toffeeish malt sweet body with toasted bittering edges but softly so, leafy and herbal, almost tea-ish hop bitterish finish with ongoing nutty malts and a dash of sherry-ish, warming alcohol. Very nice example of this old style, among the best I had so far, this is English ale tradition at its best.

Good stuff.

On draught at Chippenham Beer Festival. Black. Aroma is rum, red fruits. Medium body, a bit fizzy on the finish. Some burn from alcohol.

Draught/bottle. Black with ruby reflexes, small beige head. In aroma roasted malt, coffee, dried fruits, nuts and hint of vanilla. In taste malty, some caramel, molases, dried fruits with low roastiness in the end. Medium bodied, smooth, low carbonation. In draught version metalic notes. Complex yet very drinkable. Nice stuff.

It is pretty heavy in taste, which makes you immediately understand this is an old ale. ABV is not super high (7%) but the heaviness is present. I understand it is on purpose and I like it.

660 ml bottle. Pitch black. Small dark head. Soft toffee aroma with notes of coffee, charcoal and chocolate. Soft aroma with nuts and roasted malts. Rich and soft velvety texture. Not that sweet, but the beer is chewy and rich. Powdery and oily at the same time. Nicely balanced. Very nice.

66cl bottle at H√•ndverkerstuene.. Best before 2014-03-31. It poured a black colour with no head. Aroma is berries, lots of berries. Vanilla and honey, black and red current. Faint notes of malts and coffee. Flavour is very mild. Mostly coffee, but notes of alcohol, cocoa and vanilla. The berries in the aroma is mostly missing, though some dried fruits like plum or raisins are noticable. Medium long aftertaste.
UPDATED: JUL 17, 2016 On tap. Nose a bit on the winy side, smells like old barrel. Heavy and musty aroma. Lots of basement notes in the taste, musty and winy.

Bottle, 15C. Black with an inch of tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, prunes, vanilla. Velvety mouthfeel, but quite astringent - goes from very smooth to a little sharp at each sip. Taste has sweet mocha, dried fruits and vanilla. Earthy and tangy. Slight alcohol burn. Bitterness almost pops out at the end with astringent coffee and late-arriving dried orange peel. Deep and interesting, but doesn¬ít quite mesh as a whole. Might well come together on keeping, but very good now.

Bottle at home Boxing Day 2011 (2010 release)
Dark brown beer with slight creme head formation. Rich fruitcake and molasses, fairly dry and astringent malt, low carbonation.

Shared bottle @ H√•ndverkerstuene, courtesy of espenra. A black body with a moderate sized beige head. Aroma of dark malt, mocha and coffee. Flavor is smooth, sweet, dark, roasted  malt, coffee, chocolate and a hint of vanilla. Fine body and a pleasant aftertaste with dark, roasted malt, dry fruit and balanced bitterness. A fine and complex beer with lots of flavors. One of the best beer I have tasted so far from Moore.

Bottle at H√•ndverkerstuene. Thx to espenra. Black colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, licoricedried fruits. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, licorice, dried fruits. Full bodied nice beer.

660 ml bottle. Pours black with light tan head. Aromas of dark chocolate, coffee grounds, and hints of vanilla and chalk. Flavors of roasted malts, light chocolate, vanilla, and a touch of dark fruit. Smooth though a bit acidic.

An imperial porter, really. Chocolate fired up in a wooden stove and dipped in coffee, sprinkled with anise, then pulverized and fermented. OK that either sounds ridiculously good or terrible... for me it¬ís the former.
Cask conditioned at Pivni, York. Medium tan head. Dark brown body. Alcohol, red fruits, malty, chocolate, grassy hops, mild malt, chocolate malt. Sweet with a bitter alcoholic bite. Dry finish.

Dark fruits soaked in booze which I suggests christmas cake and rum. Hints of blueberry in the nose. Tasty brew that is has the rich cake flavour coupled to high notes that give hints of more sweet berries. Sweet and warming. Nice stuff.

Sampled from 66cl bottle at Beer Enthusiast release party, H√•ndverkerstuene. Pours very dar, almost black, with a small beige head. Fruity aroma with dried, dark fruits, caramel, nuts, chocolate with hints of roasted malt, coffee and vanilla. Alcohol is well integrated, but noticable. Medium to full body. Sweet and fruity with a balanced bitterness and some roasty notes in the finish. Liquid dessert! Sweet, but surprisingly pleasant.

On bottle at H√•ndverkerstuene.
Black color, some foam.
Aromas of coffee, licorice, lots of dried fruit & malt.
Quite noticeable yeast influence.medium/full body & high complexity.
Immediate sweetness, some bitterness.
Enjoyable, but to sweet for my taste

(Bottle during RBWG) milkshake medium brown pour, no head. Nose of medium dark chocolate, raisins, light alcohol, meaty. Smells pretty decent but tastes terrible. Taste of campfire, smoke, dark chocolate, umami, watery in body and gross.
Cask. Dark brown, beige head. Nose is plums, brown sugar, chocolate, anise. Taste is plums, brown sugar, chocolate pudding, plum Starburst. Great mouthfeel.

Handpull at Southampton Arms. Nearly opaque black with an average slightly diminishing beige-tan creamy foamy head. Aroma of a treacly fruit porter with coffee and raisins, some light herbal bitterness. Taste follows, but better - anise, a bit of charred tarry rope - I get very little alcohol. Slick, average body, mild carbonation, nice fruity/oily deep roast finish. Pretty damned solid stuff.

Cask @ Stockbridge Tap, Edinburgh EIBF
Black with ruby edges in glass, thin tan head, some lacing
Aroma of dark rich caramel, rich dark fruit malts, rich fruit cake spices, hint of liquorice, yes there is some Xmas pudding in there
Taste as aroma, rich dark fruity malts, gorgeous flavour, soft bitter roast, slight soft liquorice, alcohol well hidden, complex fruity malt  with mellow dark fruit cake spices. Superb.
Palate - soft carb, full bodied, smooth mouthfeel, bit sticky. Finish as main flavour with nice linger and light bitter roast
Overall - Best Moor beer for me so far, great flavour, seems like a hybrid of old ale / porter to me. Good winter warmer ale.
Pours brown with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, mineral, light coffee and light chocolate. Flavour is roasted malt, mineral, coffee and chocolate.

Pours a clear and dark brown beer with a weak beige head. The aroma is malt, caramel, alcohol, slate, roasted and chocolate. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness and a low level of carbonation. Overall a good beer.

2nd September 2009Opaque black beer. Soft palate, a tad dry and just moderate carbonation. Rich dark malt with a mild toast. Tangy start blossoms in to a sweetish mid with banana and bubblegum esters. Finishes soft with mild hop bitterness. Dry finish with toasted malt aftertaste.

Bottle @ home. Deep sludgy brown color with basically no head or sign of carbonation. The nose is thick molasses, milk chocolate, mud, fruit leather, museli breakfast cereal. The taste is dark autumn fruits, sludgy day-old roasted coffee. spicy chutney and ash. Light bitter finish. Slightly hot, you feel the 7.5%. This feels under-carbonated and a bit lethargic. The beer¬ís only 5 months old, so I don¬ít think it¬íll have lost much life than a fresh bottle example. Still, this isn¬ít my favorite offering from a usually top brewer.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 Zero head, zero carbonation, taste is a fruity porter which isn¬ít bad but really let down by the fact its as flat as a pancake with no life whatsoever. A bad bottle maybe, but what a let down, and this wasn¬ít cheap either

bottle . pours very dark brown - almost black with just a glimpse of tan head before it disappeared .aroma is coffee , burnt sugar and some chocolate . taste is similar with a pleasant bitter aftertaste  . carbonation is very low and there is a thin oily mouthfeel. hides alcohol very well . drinkable but a bit more carbonation and body would improve it
Bottle. Dark brown with an underdeveloped  tan head. Roasted coffee been bitterness. Burnt wood. Some chocolate. A bit of pruney goodness. A let down ultimately. I thought this was gonna be tidy.
50 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK. Jet black, zero head. Burnt coffee aroma with a background of herbal-spice hops.Very smooth, chalky with a sweet vanilla and wood-smoke finish.

(66cl bottle, courtesy of crusinbeer)  Pours an opaque black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of banana, chocolate, and roasted malt.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, and some dark fruit.

A tasty offering that would have rated considerably higher if it did look so poor.
Big chunks in the pour, on the cap, and in bottle neck.
Black,  tan head that fades immediately. Roasty brown sugar nose.
Rich roasted profile with wood overtones and medium alcohol heat
UPDATED: MAY 19, 2012 Dark brown almost black color with a fine brown head. Roasted malt aroma. Sweet and again roasted taste. Slightly thin..

Bottle shared during RBWG 2012. Pours a dark brown with a small beige head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is a strong banana and roast. Thin mouthfeel with a banana flavor and light roast finish. Easyto drink a verygoo porter from Moors.
Bottle shared during RBWG 2012  Black with a small tan head and some lacing. Roasted malts, chocolate and some bitterness. OK.

Tasted this at the Troon Beer Festival in October 2006. Cask, gravity dispense. Black mahogany in colour with a thin creamy buff head. Rich christmas cake notes in the heavy, intense sweet aroma. Thick double cream mouthfeel and good lacing. Dark malts give a rich complex maltloaf base with a plethora of flavours. Taste resembles a very strong Dark Island with rich mocha coffee, strong dark chocolate and then sweet notes of caramel, raisins and molasses come through. Hops must have been removed two minutes into the boil as little if any hop resin detected. Strong, booming, complex malt notes full in the mouth, chocolate Prize bar comes to mind! An interesting vanilla pod infused  ice cream flavour comes through at the very end. A fantastic complex porter this and highly recommended. Worth the effort seeking this out in cask.  Very popular at the Troon festival - impressive stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 Pours with hardly any head. In fact no fizz at all and a slightly flat mouthfeel. Rich berry notes initially, then fruitcake and dusty dark choc. Banana notes follow and a milky feeling in and around the finish. Very smooth. Very easy to drink. ABV doesn¬ít show. Very impressive.

Botttle. Pours deep black with very fast-fading tan head. Aromas of vanilla and chocolate, almost a sweet marmite, with banana leaf and redcurrant notes. The banana is quite pronounced on the flavour, along with a bit more coffee and chocolate than is on the nose. A pleasant CO2 tingle on the palate. Very nice beer indeed.

On cask at the Marble Arch. A black beer with a decent tan head. Aroma of caramel, chocolate, coffee and roasty malt. Similar flavours with alcohol fairly present and lingering roasty malt. Moderate carbonation, an oily mouth-feel and a little CO2 prickle. Quite dry to finish with a hint of apple seed.

Pours a deep near-black with no head at all and a sweet prune aroma. Chocolate and roasted malt flavour, plenty of date, prune, and all that good stuff. Perhaps the merest hint of carbonation, medium body. This is dangerously sippable, very well-balanced, rich, and tasty.
660ml bottle at 7.4%.  Pours black with no head.  Aroma is sour blackcurrant and roast coffee.  Taste has blackcurrant and wood to start.  Sour coffee finish.  Barely any carbonation.

From SkjoldBurne, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled, 211211.
Black with beige head. Aroma of coffee. Flavor with liqourice, caramel and fruit.
66cl, at 7.5%Vol, English brew, from Beermerchants.com, complex Porter, malty/roasted and slightly salty/fruity, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good Winter brew, yet expensive!

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours solid black with a small tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, espresso, and toasted nuts. Flavour of dark chocolate, espresso, toasted nuts and roasted malts. Medium-to-full bodied, roasted and lightly smoky.
light smoked aroma,black, brown foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Almost looks like a Guiness, almost black, has a light brown head, medim durati√≥n and soft. Sweet aroma, notes of sweet fruit and soy-sauce. Sweet starting flavor, some soy sauce, smoke laqurice, nice. Creamy terxture. Soft carbonation.

660ml bottle pours almost black in color with a minimal beige head and very thin lacing.  Aromas of roasted malts and a hint of fruit.  Taste is roasted malty sweetness with some fruitiness and finishing with a pleasing hop bitterness and some chocolate.  Complex and nicely balanced ale which I really enjoyed sampling.

660mL bottle, split 3 ways, pours dark brown / black with almost no head. Aroma of dark fruits (cherries), chocolate, caramel and brown sugar. Flavour of chocolate, brandied fruits and some roasted malt. Oily, silky palate. Decent.

Cask at Southampton Arms. Very black coloured with small beige head. Aroma is cherry, booze and christmas pudding. Bit of a solvent/spirit smell too. Very full on. Taste is very sweet, more booze, marzipan and rich dried fruit. Full bodied and bit oily in the mouth. Not as exciting as I had hoped.

One of my favourite dark beers. Coal black, yellowy cream head. Soft mouthfeel followed by a really complex set of flavours. Liquorice and dry roasted malt bitterness. A nice hoppy aftertaste as well.

66ml bottle from Brewery Creek in Vancouver. Pours a jet black with thin mocha cap. Aroma is lusciously deep with dark fruit, caramel, some cocoa. Taste is full on cocoa, brandied fruit, sweet caramel. This tastes more stout than porter, the mouthfeel is viscous and not watery. Very good.

In short: A sweet porter with a bit of everything except carbonation.  Ok.
How: From a bottle at Mondial de la Bi√®re 2011
The look: Near black body with almost no head
In long: Nose of sweet and fruity ¬ìdark¬î stuff.  Taste is oily black cake, some dark fruits, a cold cup of black coffee, some tobacco leafs, soft black liquorice candy.  A bit too sweet for my own taste but I would have probably enjoyed it more if it wasn¬ít for the deficient carbonation.  As it is, it was just ok.  Rating #4200 for me!!!  A milestone I¬ím happy to share with my ratebeer friends, because in movies they change the names to protect the innocents, on ratebeer we chose nicknames and stupid avatars to protect us from our spouses.

Bottle, shared by Parksy. Pours a nearly still opaque dark brown. Aroma is rich chocolate and dark fruits, hints of blueberries even, very enticing. Full bodied, with heaps of flavour, lovely fudgey chocolate, plums, blueberries, background flavours of treacle, vanilla, black tea. Soft silky mouthfeel. Light acidity in the finish. Good length to the flavours. This is the most satisfying porter I¬íve had in a while, and one with old-school english character. I need to find more of this!

text:
Sample at Mondial 2011.

Appearance : Pitch black with small head.

Aroma : Lots of coffee, light chocolate and light acidity. 

Taste : Great coffee with light chocolate and again light acidity. 

Overall : Nice chocolate and nice coffee. Quite complex. Not sure about the acidity.
Almost black with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and a little dried fruit. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted bitter finish. 020711

Poured out a near black brew with dark red hues with a fizzy brown cap that vanishes instantly. Really good aroma with depth. Roast, mild molasses, vanilla, light spices, plums, warm chocolate, faint hints of coffee, raspberry. The flavour is pretty good as well with hidden characteristics. Mild bitterness, licorice, hints of salt, roasted malts, plenty of richness, alcohol, plum, I dig but don¬ít love.. maybe it¬ís the extra alcohol. Fairly smooth with an alcoholic bite and sweetness and ends malty and strong. This is a good beer - a beer worthy of another go.

Sample, Mondial de la bi√®re, savoured on June 9 2011; eye: black, opaque, tiny ring of cappuccino head, no lacing; nose: roasted malt, candied fruits, molasses, dark chocolate, coffee; mouth: roasted malt, candied fruits, molasses, dark chocolate, coffee, finale in roasted malt with presence of acridness, medium-full body, not much carbonation, oily texture; overall: fine

drank at mondial 2011 in mtl. pours very dark brown with a little head, some retention and lacing. aroma is cocoa beans, vanilla, alcohol. taste is full of smoke, loads of bitter chocolate and coffee, hint of sweetness. medium grassy hopping, medium body, smooth, soft carbonation.
(Bottle 2 / 7 - 2011) < mobile > low brown head, black color, roasted aroma, roasted taste, slightly thin malt body

A deep dark porter with a thin moka head. A smooth lighly smoked chocolate aroma, doughy, and light alcohol. In mouth, a smooth lightly peaty chocolate, light alcohol, coffee grinds, pretty decent. Bottle at Mondial 2011, June 9, 2011.

Bottle sampled at Mondial de la bi√®re 2011 (Montr√©al). Black body with a thin beige head with poor retention. Aroma is chocolate, some banana bread and alcohol. Flavor is tobacco, ashes, chocolate, herbal hops, roasted malt and alcohol. Medium body.

Tasting at the 18th Mondial de la bi√®re, June 8, 2011. Blackened brown, no head. Aroma of berries, caffeinated chocolate. Taste of coffee berries, little bitterness of coffee very malty. Very pleasant without the sensation alcohol!

My Bottom Line:
This complex Porter presents raisins, coffee beans, chocolate and licorice in an oily and sweet body which might get cumbersome after a while.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam circles the dark brown.
-The low carbonation makes the body feel heavier.
-Fruity angles don¬ít necessarily mesh with the bold coffee flavors.
-The complexity is impressive, but drinkability is too low for my tastes in the style.
-Fruitiness nears on being acetic at times.

Bottle.

Eher milder Antrunk, in dem die Malzigkeit nur bedingt durchdringt, andere Aromen sind leider ebenfalls rar. Zum Ende trocken, daf√ºr intensiver, wenig fruchtig in eine blumige Hopfenrichtung. /9/8/8//8
Bottle. Very dark brown with small light brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, bitter, chocolate, coffee, liquorice, hops and a little sweet.
Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly deminishing head. Black colour. Moderate malty and hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter flavor. Long heavy bitter finish. Strong english licorice notes. Creamy palate.
Bottle @ Torben Mathews tasting. Medium head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, milk, licorice, chocolate, caramel and hops.

Bottled Thx tkrjukoff.
Black with a bubbly, beige head.
Milky chocolate. Slightly sourish.
A bit vinous with sweet fruits.
Bottle. Black beer with a creamy beige head. Chocolate aroma, hops, cocoa and some spicy notes. Spicy malty flavor, chocolate and cocoa, slightly salty.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2011 Cask at CPK. Pours a dark brown with no head. Lots of cocoa malts on the nose. Flavor has strong notes of peat and booze, light roast, light bitterness. Medium bodied, flat and very warming. Finishes peaty, warming, lightly sweet with some roasty cocoa beans. Pretty nice.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2011 Cask/gravity at Battersea BF 2011. Pours black edged with brown and a fine clingy beige crema, nose has treacle, demerara, alcohol, a little coffee and a hint of oak, then a big chewy body with a syrupy character perfectly balanced by a dry hoppiness and the alcoholic bite. Dry-roast after taste with more treacle notes. More like a strong Burton than a porter, but excellent either way. Re-rated at the Magpie, this time there¬ís also a little red fruit noticeable on the nose, plus a hint of fruity tartness on the tongue and a touch of spice in the dry-sweet finish.

Cask at Cask Pub and Kitchen, Pimlico, London. A black coloured pour with a medium beige head. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee and malt. Tastes of dark chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, dark fruit. A lovely rich, warming porter that I always have when I see it on cask.

Shared bottle (marked 7,5%) thx to tkrjukoff, cons 2011-02-04 Billdal
AR: souriness, chocloate
AP: dark brown body, brown beige head
F: sourness, chocolate, medium + bitterness

Pours black with a rich brown head leaving some lace. Aroma is sweet malty, fruity, dark fruits and hoppy. Sourish fruity mouthfeel. Fruity, tary, malty and sourish flavor. Fruity palate. Finishes shortlived dry tart.

66 cl bottle thanks to tkrjukoff! On February 4, 2011Marked 7.5% ABVVery dark brown to black color, dark brown head. Sweet, licorice, malty, fruity, alcohol scent. Salty, grainy, licorice taste. Salty aftertaste, then comes a hoppy and grainy aftertaste as well after a while. Sort of thin mouthfeel, medium bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2011 (Bottle) Pours near black with pale brown head. The aroma is roasted, fruity and light spicy with a touch of Swedish julmust. Blackberries and salty, light sweet liquorice. The flavour is light sweet, light to medium bitter and tiny acidic. Dark chocolate, cocoa, mild coffee, spices, fruits and light julmust. The mouthfeel is round and light oily with a tiny tart finish. Light carbonation. Roast and a touch of hops on the finish. Medium bodied.
Black with no head. Roast aroma, licorice and rubber. Sweet flavour with an artificial caramel candy note. Dry finish.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark brown colour, medium beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, liquorice and dark fruits. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, fruits, nutty. Fairly bitter finish. Nice stuff.
Very tasty beer, hints of dark chocolate, vanilla and coffee. Rich and full bodied, light fizz, tan head

660 ml bottle.  Dark brown with a fluffy tan cap.  Nose is vanilla, dates, rum raisin and mild coffee.  Milky medium body with a faint tang but mostly flat.  Unlike the rich and malty aroma, the taste is oddly devoid of sweetness.  Baker¬ís chocolate, ash and grass.  Finishes earthy with raw potato and licorice.  Has a rustic appeal but overall kind of gritty.
Bottle. Dark brown and beige head. Roasted and chocolate and liquorice aroma. Roasted malts in the mouth and alcohl, light bitter. Medium body.
Bottle,Black with a large coffee coloured head,aroma of dark chocolate,vanilla,blackberry and some alcohol,taste of dark choc and malt,alcohol presence is too strong and ruins it for me.

Cask at the Southampton Arms, London on 4th December 2010. Thick black with meniscus head of rich pale-brown foam. Rich, pungent aroma. Thickly fruity in-mouth with spices, Christmas pudding/mince pies and winter berries. Spicy and herby late-on and a bitter finish rounded by thick fruitcake and caramel. Fascinating ale, well crafted, lovely for supping by the fire while the snow is falling outside.

Bottle.  Black with a thin beige foam.  Aromas are spicy and herbal with dark treacle and vinous red wine notes.  Soy with coffee and burnt toffee.  Dark chocolate with bready yeast and peppery alcohol and hints of marzipan.  Flavours are molasses with dry, fruity red wine.  Blackberry and grape with dark chocolate.  Some nutty, woody notes.  Dry and earthy on the finish with grapefruit bitterness.  Good.

bottle from Darts Farm Topsham. Deep brown colour, almost black, small beige head. Arom aof fresh baking yeast, after a while aroma of coffee, chocolate and dark fruit. Full-bodied, caramel, roasetd malts, bitter chocolate, espresso, raisins, dates, prunes.... complex, very pleasant and smooth palate. A delicious beer.
Courtesy of fiulijn. Chocolatey with a lot of plum components throughout. Sweet and complex. Extremely pleasant

courtesy of fiulijn - dark brown colour with a little dark beige foam; toasted malty nose with notes of chocolate and licorice; creamy palate and medium-bodied; fairly bitter and with a long chocolatey and slightly nutty finish
Bottle from Kris Wines.Almost black with a small capuccino head.Rich fruity chocolate nose with some roast. More fruit in the mouth, with bittering roast in the finish. A wonderful night cap.

On cask at 4:20. Pours black witha creamy longlasting tan head. The aroma is sweet caramel, light chili, dark fruit, light spicy and have notes of chocolate. The flavour is light chili, sweet caramel, light roasted, some chocolate and dark fruit. Complex and very delicious!
Cask @ 4:20, Rome. Pours black with a small creamy white head and lacings. Nose is roast, chocolate and coffee. Low carbonation. Coffee beans and a bit of smoke. Vinous, stikcy and smooth. Nice
Bottle. Black with a small head.Fruity with a dry finish and a medium body. Very well balanced and all round an excellent drink.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2011 Smells of good barnyard aka stilton, peat and chocolate. Taste is pretty much the same. A smooth texture. Also some vanilla; roasted malts and caramel.. This is a really well made English porter-old ale. I¬ím really impressed. Thanks Reakt for the recomendation to get some Moor. I would love to have this on tap and fresh. 

Bottle Home - 7th January 2010. Bought from a shop in Glastonbury. Bottle. 660ml. 

Poured into goblet glass; excellent lacing, really nice creamy-white, black and opaque. Smell is Peat; leather, liquorish, stilton and dried fruits. Taste is plums, leather, liquorish, cream, raisins, candi sugar, toffee-syrup. some burnt malts and a nice smokey-peaty finish.  There is also a little stilton I feel. Still a 4.0

Bottle.

A - Dark cola black with a large, frothy, creamy, rocky tan head with above average retention and a nice bit of creamy lacing left.

S - Strong roasted espresso coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malt smell. Good amount of dark fruit (blackberry, date, black currant and raisin), licorice, and some brown sugar/molasses. 

T - Initially there is a pretty strong dark fruit (similar to the nose) and chocolate taste. This is slightly tart and slightly sweet. Then a heavy amount of roasted malt, coffee, and other roasted slightly bitter porter flavors come in. Also present is a touch of licorice and brown sugar along with the dark fruit. This creates a slightly bitter taste with some sweetness and tartness to balance it out a bit. On the finish, some earthy flavors become present and the dark fruit makes a strong comeback and lingers on the tongue.

M - Medium body with medium carbonation. Smooth and a bit creamy.

D - Good drinkability. Well balanced flavors, with there being some strong porter flavors but not necessarily heavily roasted flavors but a good amount of fruitiness. Good easy to drink porter that is a little on the higher side of ABV. 

Notes: ABV = 7.5%. Enjoyable porter that is well balanced and tasty. Nothing outstanding about it, but it is good and easy to drink. Fruity, roasted, and porter flavors are good. Definitely worth a try.

Pours a deep black colour with the hint of purple/red around the very edges of the glass with a lively tan/light brown head which diminishes over time. Aroma is fruity with notes of plum, dark chocolate, coffee, earth and ash. Flavour is more of the same with an added sweetness, some raisins, burnt sugar, molasses. Finish is more fruit, chocolate, nice and dry, maybe some hops, lots of earth and spice. Good beer.

Draft @ √òrsted √òlbar, Copenhagen. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty licorice aroma with some hints of chocolate. Has a sweetish roasted malty chocolate and licorice flavor. Sweetish slightly roasted malty chocolate finish with some hints of licorice in the aftertaste.
Draught at √òlbaren.Pitch black colour with creamy beige head.Aroma of dark chocolate and rosted coffee,nice smooth mouthfeels and creamy mild flavor of caramel.

Very dark brown with a brown and small, but firm head. Aroma is quite strong and pleasant: dried fruit, coffee, roasted malt, licorice, touch of burnedness. Flavor is sweetish and fruity, licoricey, but also dry and roasty - even slightly burned. Burnedness is not irritating, though, with lots of other flavors to cover it. Almost full-bodied, and smooth despite the slight ashiness and foamy carbonation. A pleasant, roasty and full old ale.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2010 Dark opaque brown, thin tan head. Chocolate, nuts, candy sugar, spices. Full-bodied, rich fruitcake, chocolate, fruity, earthy/flowery hops, coffee. Lacking a little end-palate but a very decent winter warmer.

Cask at Turf Tavern, a while back.
Aroma of chocolate, caramel. Well roasted yet not burnt. Quite fruity and relatively sweet. Rich, strong, flavorful. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2011 2010-08-21, bottle, 7.5% ABV, 6-4-6-3-12=31Black color; small head. Chocolate brew, bit the light sourness that is usually associated to Old Ales; the aroma is mild; the flavor is just better; but tasted just after the Fusion it¬ís not as good.2009-10-09, draught at √òrsted, Copenhagen, 7.3% ABV, 6-3-7-3-13=32Black color. The body is weaker than the alcohol may suggest. There is some caramel and chocolate flavor, light residual sweetness, but also a yeast presence, both the aroma and flavor. Nothing special.

Bottle 66 cl. Courtesy of madmitch76. Pours an opaque black with a tiny, light brown head. Hard roasted malt in the nose, dried fruit and a little wood.
